awd_titl_txt: Access to Justice among the Rural Poor in Minnesota and Wisconsin
awd_abstract_narration:
Title:  Access to Justice Among the Rural Poor


Individuals who are poor often do not have access to legal services. Civil legal aid provides some legal services to poor individuals, but usually not enough to meet their legal needs.  As well, these individuals may not seek access to justice because may not be aware that their disputes are legal in nature, or because they are not aware they may have access to legal help.  This project engages in an ethnographic study of the rural poor in northern Minnesota and Wisconsin, as it seeks to examine this population's conceptions of access to justice, and to understand why these individuals usually do not pursue legal services. 

By engaging in a broad range of interdisciplinary approaches on rural poverty, this project addresses theoretical issues on legal mobilization from the perspective of law and society as well as socio-legal studies of legal advocacy and legal mobilization. The project will explore the complex intersections of poverty, advocacy, and policy in the distinct context of the rural poor in Minnesota and Wisconsin. Methodological approaches include observation, archival and legal analyses, and interviews. This sustained, multi-sited and diverse methodological approach will provide a rigorous and comparative consideration of rural access to justice.

por.por_cntn:
The project, "Access to Justice among the Rural Poor in Minnesota and Wisconsin," (#1729117) has documented how rurality impacts low-income individuals' conceptions of and efforts to mobilize law. It has also explored the unique challenges of civil legal aid provision across diverse rural communities, and the ways in which tribal and state court judges address professional deserts, underresourced rural court systems, insufficient infrastructure, and other barriers to accessing justice. With supplemental funding, I extended this research to collaboratively evaluate the Lac Courte Oreilles Ojibwe University's efforts to develop a lay advocacy program in Wisconsin as a unique, community-driven access to justice initiative.

Intellectual Merit

Engaging novel, cross-disciplinary frameworks and audiences, this project mobilized diverse data in theoretically significant and publicly relevant ways. This is evidenced in the publications emerging from the research, which include peer-reviewed and law review articles on rural access to justice (Pruitt et al. 2018; Statz 2021; Statz forthcoming); rurally-relevant access to justice practices and policies (Statz, Friday & Bredeson 2020); place-informed research methods (Statz and Garriott 2022); rurality as an axis of concordance (Statz, Billings and Wolf, 2020); rural legal deserts as a health disparity (Statz and Termuhlen 2020); and rurality and gender in/justice (Statz and Evers 2020; Statz and Pruitt 2019). Critically, these publications have been placed in journals spanning the fields of socio-legal studies, law, public health, sociology, geography, psychology and criminology. 

Broader Impacts

It is rare for rural access to justice initiatives to expressly consider the diverse concerns that rural low-income individuals themselves prioritize, whether rural attorneys share and are equipped to address these concerns, and the extent to which local interpretations of justice align with the assessments of "outside" policy makers. This research project has addressed these gaps through two extensive community legal need assessments on behalf of partnering civil legal aid organizations; an online ?Rural A2J Guide? for legal practitioners and lawmakers; a robust research website (northlandproject.org); ongoing community speaking events; and over 15 invited or keynote speeches to tribal court judges, state bar associations, and judicial branches. Over the course of this research, I have trained and mentored undergraduate, graduate, law, medical, and tribal lay advocacy students in research methodologies, data ethics and sovereignty, and data analysis, writing, and public speaking. The majority of these students are underrepresented in their disciplines. Owing to this project, I have also developed and had unanimously approved a course at the University of Minnesota Medical School entitled "Justice, Law, and Medicine"--the first of its kind to expressly consider the structural determinants of health (including law and policy) and the ways in which they variously impact Indigenous and/or rural community members in the regions where our students most typically work. 

This project is arguably the first sustained, empirical consideration of rural access to justice in the United States. Through it, I have been able to develop robust networks of tribal and state court judges, engage policy makers at various levels (state and now also federal, via my invovlvement with the new Rural Justice Taskforce), and help design and build the new "Law and Rurality" Law and Society Association Collaborative Research Network. The opportunity to conduct this research has changed my life as a scholar and human; it has compelled me to publicize my data--many of which are incredibly urgent and not well known--as widely as possible, and it has allowed me to meaningfully honor the lived expertise of rural community members in my writing, teaching, and speaking across diverse public audiences.
